intro: Solanum nigrum subvar. atriplicifolium, commonly known as black nightshade, is a flowering plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is characterized by its small, dark purple to black berries that mature in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and alternate, heart-shaped leaves. Its flowers are yellow and clustered in umbels, and the plant is often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. It is part of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and contains toxic compounds, making it potentially harmful if ingested.
